Key Arguments: The proposed legislation lacks clarity in its objectives, making it difficult for the regulator to achieve proportionality, fairness, and transparency.
The exemptions for certain entities like Australian governments, media outlets, and universities are problematic and could lead to misuse of the law.
The definitions of harm are vague and could lead to misdirected regulatory efforts.
The legislation does not adequately address the role of states, organizations, and institutions in influence operations.
The approach is reactive rather than proactive, focusing on enforcement rather than prevention.
The legislation could lead to increased government control over media and ideas, reducing regulatory independence.
Notable Quotes: The regulator is more likely to become a tool of misinformation rather than a harm prevention agency for the people.
The intent of this Law appears to operate contrary to this central tenet of information warfare and selects instead the more problematic path of silencing voices.
This skewed view of harm will mean the regulator will continually chase unnecessary and ill-formed group victim complaints.
The proposed law appears to stigmatize platforms as part of the problem â€“ needing enforcement.
